statement.tex: Find the domain and range of the following function \[ \qquad f(x) = \fx \]

options.tex: %text $f(x) = \fx$ is defined for all $x \in\mathbb{R}$. Hence, its domain is $\mathbb{R}$ \incorrect $f(x) = \fx$ is defined \underline\text{only for} $x > 1$. Hence, its domain is $(1,\infty)$%
%text $f(x) = \fx$ is defined \underline\text{only for} $x > 1$. Hence, its domain is $(1,\infty)$%

reason.tex: %text Had $f(x) = \dfrac{1}{\fx}$, then yes, one would have to worry about the deonominator turning $0$ (at $x=1$) But if $f(x) = \fx$, then there is no such problem. In fact, $f(x)$ is defined for any $x\in\mathbb{R}$. Therefore the domain is $\mathbb{R}$%
